questions.text: A clinician touched the eyes of a patient with a piece of cotton, and rapid blinking of eyes occurred in response. What is the structure responsible for carrying the above sensation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Trigeminal nerve

The response of blinking when the clinician touches the patient’s eye with a piece of cotton is known as the corneal reflex. The sensation is transmitted by the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V), while the motor response Is controlled by the facial nerve (CN VII).
The corneal reflex Is an involuntary, protective response that causes blinking when the cornea is stimulated, such as by a light touch. It serves as a defence mechanism to prevent foreign objects from entering the eye and causing damage. The reflex involves two main components: sensory input and motor output. The sensation of touch or irritation on the cornea is detected by the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V), specifically its nasociliary branch, which sends the signal to the brainstem.

questions.text: After a roller coaster ride, a person experiences a brief sense of imbalance before standing upright. Which tract helps maintain balance in this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Vestibulospinal Tract

After a roller coaster ride, a person feels a slight imbalance and takes a minute to stand upright. The tract responsible for maintaining balance in this situation is the vestibulospinal tract.
Vestibular nuclei are situated in the pons and medulla oblongata beneath the floor of the fourth ventricle. The vestibular nuclei receive afferent fibres from the inner ear through the vestibular nerve and from the cerebellum. Neurons of the lateral vestibular nucleus give rise to the axons that form the vestibulospinal tract. The tract descends uncrossed through the medulla and through the length of the spinal cord in the anterior white column. The fibres terminate by synapsing with internuncial neurons of the anterior grey column of the spinal cord.

questions.text: The lymph nodes located at the site indicated by the arrow are classified under which level?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Level 2

The lymph nodes at the arrow-marked position are classified as level 2. The upper jugular group of lymph nodes corresponds to level 2 neck lymph nodes.
The cervical lymph nodes filter lymph and support immune defense. They are divided into superficial (along the external jugular vein) and deep (along the internal jugular vein) groups. They drain lymph from the head, face, and neck, including the scalp, nasal, and oral cavities, helping fight infections.

questions.text: A patient presents with a hypopigmented patch behind the ear with loss of sensation. Neck examination reveals a thickened structure, as shown in the image below. What is this structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Greater auricular nerve

In the given clinical scenario, the patient presents with a hypopigmented patch behind the ear accompanied by loss of sensation, and neck examination reveals a thickened structure suggestive of leprosy, and the thickened structure is the greater auricular nerve.

questions.text: A primigravida woman gives birth to a baby with the following defect. Identify the anomaly.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Open neural tube defect

Craniorachischisis is a severe neural tube defect where failure of closure causes exposed brain (anencephaly) and spinal cord (rachischisis), resulting in an open brain and spine. It occurs early in development and is incompatible with life.

choices.text: Improper fusion of both the membranous and muscular portions of the interventricular septum
Improper fusion of the membranous portion of the interventricular septum
Improper development of the muscular portion of the interventricular septum
Improper fusion of the endocardial cushions

questions.text: A 1-month-old baby is diagnosed with ventricular septal defect (VSD) and patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). The VSD is caused by ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Improper fusion of both the membranous and muscular portions of the interventricular septum

A ventricular septal defect (VSD) results from incomplete fusion of the muscular and membranous parts of the interventricular septum during embryonic development. The muscular septum forms from the ventricular floor, while the membranous septum develops from endocardial cushions and conotruncal ridges. Failure of these structures to fuse creates an abnormal ventricular connection, starting around the 4th week of gestation.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles will be paralyzed if there is an injury to the nucleus underlying the marked structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lateral rectus
The image shows the floor of the fourth ventricle, and the facial colliculus is marked. The abducens nucleus lies underneath the facial colliculus. Injury to the abducens nucleus will lead to paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle.
The facial colliculus, on the floor of the fourth ventricle at the lower pons, contains the abducens nucleus and facial nerve fibers forming the internal genu. The abducens nerve (CN VI) emerges between the pons and medulla, passes through Dorello’s canal, then enters the superior orbital fissure via the cavernous sinus to innervate the lateral rectus muscle.

questions.text: Identify the structure in the given image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Blastocyst

The arrow is pointing at Blastocyst.
Around the 4th/5th day of development, the morula becomes the blastocyst. Fluid passes into the morula from the uterine cavity and converts it to a blastocyst with a fluid-filled cavity called blastocoele. This fluid partially separates the cells of the inner cell mass from the outer cell mass.

choices.text: Descending Limb of the Loop of Henle

questions.text: Which segment of the nephron has the lowest osmolality in the absence of the ADH hormone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cortical Collecting Duct

In the absence of antidiuretic hormone (ADH), the cortical collecting duct has the lowest osmolality.
As filtrate moves through the nephron, it changes concentration. Initially, in the proximal tubule, water and solutes are reabsorbed in equal proportions, keeping the filtrate isotonic (-300 mOsm/L). In the loop of Henle, water is removed in the descending limb, increasing osmolality, while solutes are actively reabsorbed in the ascending limb, diluting the filtrate to ~100 mOsm/L by the time it reaches the early distal convoluted tubule.

questions.text: Which of the following cells is responsible for the removal of small foreign particles trapped in the lungs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Dust cells

Dust cells, or pulmonary alveolar macrophages, originate from the bone marrow and remove small particles in the lungs. They engulf particles that bypass the mucociliary escalator, attract immune cells, and stimulate blood cell production. However, in response to irritants like cigarette smoke, they can release substances that cause inflammation.

choices.text: Ttricuspid valve bulging into right atria

questions.text: In the Jugular Venous Pressure waveform what does the “a” wave correspond to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Atrial contraction

‘A’ wave of the JVP corresponds to atrial contraction.

questions.text: In a patient, after administration of Noradrenaline injection, the heart rate started to decrease. What is the reason behind it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Stimulation of baroreceptors

The decrease in heart rate (bradycardia) after noradrenaline (norepinephrine) injection is due to the stimulation of baroreceptors (baroreceptor reflex, also known as the baroreflex).
Noradrenaline causes vasoconstriction via alpha-1 receptors, raising blood pressure. This activates baroreceptors, leading to increased vagal tone and decreased sympathetic activity, resulting in reflex bradycardia.

questions.text: A person is performing weightlifting and attempts to lift the dumbbells overhead. Which of the following changes will be seen in the sarcomere during this process?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

I band decreases

During skeletal muscle contraction, sliding of thin filament over thick filament (cross bridge formation) reduces the length of the ‘I’ band.

questions.text: A postmenopausal lady with osteoporosis is advised to remain upright for at least half an hour after administration of her medication. What side effect is being prevented by doing this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Reflux esophagitis

Bisphosphonates, used for postmenopausal osteoporosis, should be taken on an empty stomach with a full glass of water, remaining upright for 30 minutes to prevent esophageal irritation. They are not taken with food and may be combined with bedtime proton pump inhibitors to reduce symptoms.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man arrives at the emergency room with breathing difficulty and cyanosis after inhaling phosphine gas while working on a car in a garage. Despite being given pure oxygen, his oxygen levels stay low and do not improve. What type of hypoxia is most likely causing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Histotoxic hypoxia

Phosphine causes histotoxic hypoxia by inhibiting mitochondrial function and impairing cellular respiration in tissues. It blocks cytochrome oxidase (Complex IV) in the electron transport chain, stopping ATP production despite sufficient oxygen. Consequently, cells cannot utilize oxygen, making oxygen therapy ineffective as the primary treatment.

questions.text: Which one of the following is related to the release of bicarbonate in exchange for chloride in the RBC to maintain electrical neutrality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Chloride shift

The release of bicarbonate in exchange for chloride in the RBC to maintain electrical neutrality is known as the chloride shift or Hamburger phenomenon.

questions.text: Dehydration occurs in both adults and children, but children become dehydrated more easily than adults. How does the ratio of extracellular fluid (ECF) to intracellular fluid (ICF) in children differ from that in adults?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

ECF is higher than ICF

In infants and young children, the ECF is higher than ICF. This higher ECF-to-ICF ratio in children explains why they are more susceptible to dehydration.
At birth, ECF is approximately 1.5 times that of ICF. However, this changes rapidly to become almost equal to ICF by day 10 of life. ICF gradually increases in proportion to become twice as much as ECF by age 3 years, and this proportion (two-thirds of TBW is ICF and one-third of TBW is ECF) is maintained thereafter.

questions.text: A renal biopsy of a patient is shown below. Identify the cells marked in the given histological image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Macula Densa

The structure in the histological image is the macula densa cells in the distal convoluted tubule.
Specialized cells at the start of the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) form the macula densa. They detect sodium and chloride concentrations of the fluid in the tubule (chemoreceptor). In response to elevated sodium and chloride, the macula densa cells trigger the contraction of the afferent arteriole, reducing the flow of blood to the glomerulus and the glomerular filtration rate.

This happens as follows: When there is increased sodium, there is increased sodium-potassium ATPase activity which leads to increased ATP hydrolysis causing more adenosine formation. The adenosine receptors on the macula densa cells stimulate it to release more calcium, so that there is vasoconstriction of the afferent arteriole, thereby decreasing the GFR.

questions.text: The image shows the oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve plotted during different conditions. Which among the following conditions would result in curve D?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Acidosis

The oxygen hemoglobin curve denoted by the curve D will be observed during Acidosis.
Conditions that cause a right shift (C->D) in the oxygen hemoglobin curve are: (Conditions with the increased requirement of O2 – metabolically active tissues)
- Hypoxia and Hypercarbia- Metabolically active tissues utilize O2 and tissues produce CO2
- ↓pH (Acidosis)- Secondary to increased CO2 production.
- ↑in temperature, heat
- ↑ in 2,3-DPG-increased anaerobic glycolysis

questions.text: Which of the following hormone is responsible for the following natural process?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Oxytocin

Oxytocin helps in the ejection of milk by myoepithelial contraction which can be felt as cramps.
Functions of oxytocin are:
- Milk ejection (Myoepithelial contraction)
- ADH like action in high doses (reduces urine output)
- Uterine contraction

Production (Synthesis) of Milk = Prolactin

Ejection (Let-down) of Milk = Oxytocin

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency is associated with a chronic alcoholic patient presenting with gum bleeding, corkscrew hair, petechial haemorrhages, poor wound healing, and generalized weakness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Vitamin C

The given clinical scenario of a chronic alcoholic patient presenting with gum bleeding, corkscrew hair, petechial haemorrhages, poor wound healing, and generalised weakness is associated with vitamin C deficiency.
Scurvy is a disease caused by vitamin C (ascorbic acid) deficiency, leading to impaired collagen synthesis and weakened connective tissue. It commonly occurs in individuals with poor dietary intake, such as chronic alcoholics, elderly individuals, and those with malnutrition.

choices.text: Increased RBC metabolites in the urine

questions.text: A firefighter sustains electrical burns while at work. On arrival at the ED, he is hemodynamically stable. ECG monitoring and initial fluid resuscitation are started. His urine is collected for routine lab examination and appears as below. Which of the following is most likely to be found on urine analysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Myoglobin

The tea-coloured urine in the clinical vignette in the setting of an electrical injury is suggestive of rhabdomyolysis following electrical burns and the substance most likely found in this urine is myoglobin.

questions.text: A 4-day-old neonate presented with jaundice and a bilirubin level of 5 mg/dL. The most probable cause is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Physiological jaundice

The given clinical scenario of a 4-day-old neonate presenting with a bilirubin level of 5 mg/dL is suggestive of physiological jaundice.
Physiological jaundice/ Icterus neonatorum is due to increased bilirubin production from the breakdown of fetal red blood cells combined with transient limitation in the conjugation of bilirubin by the immature neonatal liver. It first appears on the 2nd or 3rd days usually peaks on the 4th day at 5-6 mg/dL and decreases to <2 mg/dL between the 5th and 7th days after birth.

questions.text: A patient presents with arthritis, and during arthroscopy, ochronosis is noted. The ferric chloride test is positive. Which of the following enzyme deficiency is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Homogentisic acid oxidase

In this clinical scenario, a patient presenting with arthritis and ochronosis (blackening of the joints) during arthroscopy with a positive ferric chloride test is suggestive of alkaptonuria, caused by a deficiency of the homogentisic acid oxidase enzyme.
Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of tyrosine metabolism, that develops due to the defect in homogentisate oxidase, which oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is excreted in the urine of a patient with essential pentosuria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

L-xylulose

L-xylulose is excreted in the urine of a patient with essential pentosuria.
Essential pentosuria is due to the lack of enzyme xylulose reductase of the uronic acid pathway. Affected individuals excrete large amounts of L-xylulose in urine. The condition is benign and does not need treatment. The only clinical relevance of this condition is that xylulose being a reducing sugar gives Benedict’s test positive which may be mistaken for diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A baby presents with chronic diarrhea and rashes on the genital region, as shown below. What is the most likely deficiency associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Zinc deficiency

The given clinical scenario of a baby with chronic diarrhea and the image showing erythematous plaques in the perineal area are suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica which is due to secondary zinc deficiency.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive zinc transporter mutation (chromosome 8q) causing zinc deficiency. Symptoms include failure to thrive, diarrhea, infections, alopecia, hypogonadism, and neurological issues like tremor, nystagmus, photophobia, hypogeusia, and irritability.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient with a reduced food intake over the past few months now presents with hypoglycemia. What is the most likely cause of hypoglycemia in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Impaired gluconeogenesis

Chronic alcoholics with hypoglycemia likely have inhibited gluconeogenesis due to ethanol metabolism. Alcohol is processed in the liver by alcohol dehydrogenase and aldehyde dehydrogenase, producing NADH. Excess NADH shifts metabolism, diverting substrates like pyruvate and oxaloacetate away from gluconeogenesis, impairing glucose production.

questions.text: Which hormone is primarily produced during starvation to regulate and maintain blood glucose levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Glucagon

Glucagon produced during starvation helps regulate and maintain blood glucose levels.
Role of insulin and glucagon:
When blood glucose falls during fasting, there is increased secretion of glucagon and decreased release of insulin.

questions.text: The RNA molecule contains the coding sequence AACACCACAC. What will be the corresponding DNA sequence from which it was transcribed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The RNA molecule contains the coding sequence AACACCACAC, which corresponds to the DNA sequence TTGTGGTGTG from which it was transcribed.

questions.text: Which enzyme is responsible for the removal of triglycerides from chylomicron?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lipoprotein lipase

The enzyme responsible for the removal of triglycerides from chylomicron is lipoprotein lipase.
Chylomicrons carry dietary lipids from the intestine to tissues, formed with apo B-48 and triacylglycerols. Apo C-II activates lipoprotein lipase, which breaks down triacylglycerols into fatty acids and glycerol for storage or energy. Deficiency in lipoprotein lipase or apo C-II (Type I hyperlipoproteinemia) causes elevated plasma chylomicrons after a fatty meal.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with malaria and family history of hemolytic anemia should have what test before starting antimalarials?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

G6PD levels

A 25-year-old male with malaria (Plasmodium vivax) and a family history of hemolytic anemia should have G6PD levels checked before starting antimalarials. G6PD deficiency, an X-linked disorder, impairs red blood cell protection against oxidative stress, leading to hemolytic anemia triggered by infections, certain drugs, or fava beans.

questions.text: A patient presented with a cold and cough. He tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 virus. What test is done to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

RT-PCR

In the clinical scenario of a patient diagnosed with SARS-CoV-2, the confirmation test performed is RT-PCR. RT-PCR is the gold standard for COVID-19 diagnosis, detecting viral RNA in respiratory samples with high sensitivity and specificity. It is a specific, simple, and effective test, especially useful for early detection.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the control of enzyme activity by phosphorylation or dephosphorylation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Covalent modification

The control of enzyme activity by phosphorylation or dephosphorylation is best explained by covalent modification.
Covalent modification regulates enzymes by adding or removing functional groups, like phosphate in phosphorylation, which can activate or inhibit their activity.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids primarily acts as a buffer in blood due to its ability to accept and donate protons at physiological pH?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Histidine

Histidine buffers blood at physiological pH due to its imidazole group (pKa 6.5–7.4), which can accept or donate protons to maintain pH stability.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes are affected during the process of collagen synthesis due to vitamin C deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Prolyl hydroxylase

Vitamin C deficiency impairs prolyl hydroxylase, disrupting collagen formation. Collagen, made in fibroblasts, has Gly-X-Y repeats with proline and hydroxyproline. Hydroxylation of proline and lysine, requiring vitamin C to keep iron reduced, stabilizes the collagen triple helix. Deficiency causes scurvy, leading to bleeding, anemia, and skeletal issues due to defective collagen.

questions.text: In the case of prolonged starvation, acetyl-CoA is mostly used for ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ketogenesis

Acetyl-CoA in prolonged starvation is mostly used for ketogenesis.
In prolonged starvation (>3 days), acetyl CoA is converted to ketone bodies in the liver which will act as the main fuel source for skeletal and heart muscles and can meet up to 20% of the brain’s energy needs.

questions.text: A 31-year-old female presents with fatigue, paleness, and dizziness. Laboratory tests reveal low serum iron levels. Given these findings and her negative iron balance, what changes in iron metabolism would be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increased Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)

A 31-year-old woman with fatigue, pallor, dizziness, and low serum iron likely has iron deficiency anemia, which shows increased TIBC. It results from inadequate iron intake, blood loss, or malabsorption, causing symptoms like fatigue, pallor, shortness of breath, and brittle nails.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with epiphora and probing reveals a soft block at 7 mm. What is the best treatment option for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Conjunctival Dacryocystorhinostomy

A soft stop 5-8 mm from the punctum implies a canalicular obstruction. Conjunctival Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) is the management of choice for proximal canalicular obstruction at 7mm. If present more than 8 mm from the punctum, the obstruction is probably at the common canaliculus.
The canalicular obstruction is divided as proximal (<8 mm from puncta) and distal (>8 mm from puncta). It can be congenital or acquired. Acquired causes are post-traumatic, repeated syringing or chronic inflammation/infection of the system. It may follow prolonged use of idoxuridine.

questions.text: A patient with a history of diabetes presents with cataract. Which of the following metabolic products is primarily responsible for cataract formation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Sorbitol

A diabetic cataract occurs due to the accumulation of sorbitol within the lens.
In diabetic patients, increased levels of blood glucose lead to high levels of glucose in the aqueous humor. The excess glucose in the aqueous humor is metabolized into sorbitol through the polyol pathway by the enzyme aldose reductase. Sorbitol is then converted to fructose (option B) by sorbitol dehydrogenase but at a much slower rate. In addition, the polar nature of sorbitol prevents its intracellular removal through diffusion.

questions.text: The cover-uncover test is performed to diagnose various eye conditions. Which of the following is not detected by this test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Amblyopia
The cover-uncover test cannot detect Amblyopia.
This test consists of two parts:
- Cover test
- Uncover test
Cover Test: This is used to detect heterotropia (Manifest Squint) (Option B). Light is first shone and corneal reflections are observed. This is done to assess fixation in the deviating eye.

choices.text: The image produced is erect and real
Condensor needs to be kept very close to the eye

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding indirect ophthalmoscopy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

It provides 3-5x magnification

An indirect ophthalmoscope produces an inverted real image of 3 to 5 times magnification.

questions.text: A patient sustained blunt trauma to the eye 6 months ago and now presents with double vision. What is the most likely condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Iriododialysis

The given image shows iridodialysis.
Iridodialysis refers to detachment of the iris root from the ciliary body and is associated with a D-shaped pupil. A black biconvex area is seen at the periphery at the site of detachment.

questions.text: A patient presents with right-sided visual field defects in both eyes while central vision remains unaffected. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing

Bilateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing involves loss of the right visual fields in both eyes, typical of occipital lobe lesions. Macular sparing occurs because the macula has a large, separate representation supplied by both posterior and middle cerebral arteries, making it less affected by strokes.

questions.text: A newborn baby brought by the mother with complaints of the left upper eyelid moving up and down during breastfeeding or thumb sucking which disappears when the baby is not being fed. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Marcus-Gunn Jaw-Winking Syndrome

Marcus-Gunn jaw-winking syndrome is a congenital condition where eyelid retraction occurs with jaw movements, caused by misdirected mandibular nerve fibers to the levator muscle. It is usually unilateral, with eyelid retraction triggered by chewing, opening the mouth, or jaw movements, and does not improve with age.

questions.text: A child presents with eyelid crusting and a gritty sensation between the eyelashes. He also has difficulty in opening eyelids. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Chronic Blepharitis

Based on the presenting symptoms – eyelid crusting, gritty sensation between eyelashes, and difficulty opening eyelids -the most likely diagnosis is chronic blepharitis.
Blepharitis is characterized by inflammation of the eyelid margins and typically presents with these exact symptoms, particularly the crusting and difficulty opening eyes in the morning due to accumulated debris.

questions.text: What is the accommodative amplitude of a patient with a near point at 20 cm and a far point at infinity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

5D

The amplitude of accommodation for the above patient would be 5 dioptres.
Near point of accommodation (NPA) is the closest distance at which the near object is clearly focussed without blur.
Amplitude of accommodation is the maximum power of the lens that permits clear near vision without blur. Its unit is dioptre (D). The amplitude of accommodation is the reciprocal of near point of accommodation (NPA) in meters.
20 cm is 1/5th of a metre. Therefore, the accommodative amplitude is its inverse, that is, 5D.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl came to your clinic with refractive power of +1D in right eye and -2D in left eye. Fundus examination reveals normal acuity and retinal findings. What is the correct diagnosis? D-dioptre
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Anisometropia

The history of defective vision and 2 different refractive errors of the eyes suggests a diagnosis of anisometropia.
Anisometropia occurs when the total refraction of both eyes are unequal. A difference of 1D in the two eyes causes a 2% difference in the size of retinal images formed. A difference up to 2.5D is well-tolerated, but beyond 4D cannot be tolerated. Anisometropia can occur as a combination of emmetropia, myopia, hypermetropia, and astigmatism.
It is diagnosed after retinoscopic examination and autorefractometry.

questions.text: What is the recommended maximum time frame for cornea harvesting after death to ensure optimal transplant quality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

6 hours

Donor corneas are to be harvested within 6 hours of death.
Eye banks manage corneal and scleral tissue donation for transplantation. The process requires next-of-kin consent and Involves screening donors for contraindications including Infectious diseases, malignancies, and neurological conditions. Tissues must be harvested within 6-8 hours of death.
Two harvesting methods are used:
1. Whole globe enucleation: Complete eyeball removal, stored in moist chamber bottles
2. In situ corneoscleral rim excision: Direct corneal rim removal into storage medium
The process is regulated by the Transplantation of Organs and Tissues Act and coordinated by the National Organ and Tissue Transplant Organization. Eye banks conduct public education and place counselors in hospitals to improve donation rates through the Hospital Cornea Retrieval Program.

questions.text: A patient has a history of a flying foreign body injury to the eye. After 8 weeks, heterochromia iridis is noted. Which of the following substances is most likely involved in the deposition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Iron

History of trauma from a flying object followed by subsequent heterochromia iridis is suggestive of siderosis bulbi which happens due to iron deposition.
The presence of iron deposits in the eye especially in industrial workers is called siderosis bulbi. It refers to the ocular degenerative changes produced by an iron foreign body. It usually occurs 2 months to 2 years after the injury. This condition is due to the electrolytic dissociation of the metal by an intrinsic resting current in the eye which disseminates the metal, combining it with cellular proteins and causing atrophy.

questions.text: A patient presents with vision problems and has a history of cataract surgery. OCT findings are given. What is the syndrome associated with these findings? OCT-Optical coherence tomography
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Irvine-Gass Syndrome

The given scenario of a patient with a history of cataract surgery and an OCT showing intraretinal cystoid spaces is suggestive of Cystoid Macular Edema (CME) in the setting of Irvine-Gass syndrome. It occurs due to the accumulation of dye in the macular region.
CME is defined as a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform (Henle’s layer) and an inner nuclear layer of the retina. This results in the formation of cyst-like cavities around the foveola. It occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier.
Common causes of CME include uveitis, previous cataract surgery (Irvine-Gass syndrome), retinal vein occlusions, diabetic retinopathy, and retinitis pigmentosa.

questions.text: A patient with CSOM presented to the OPD with seizures, headache, vomiting and photophobia. On eye examination, homonymous hemianopia was noted. CT brain showed the following findings. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Temporal lobe abscess

The clinical vignette depicting features of seizures, headache, vomiting, and photophobia in a patient with a chronic ear infection and the CT image showing a ring-enhancing lesion point to a diagnosis of a temporal lobe abscess.
Temporal lobe abscess is an intracranial complication that can arise from chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM).

questions.text: A 49-year-old female from Nagaland presented with right-sided hearing loss. On examination, a dull right tympanic membrane is noted. Enlarged lymph nodes are seen in the posterior triangle of the neck. Which of the following is the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Radiotherapy

The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with right-sided hearing loss, dull tympanic membrane (middle ear effusion leading to a conductive hearing loss) and enlarged lymph nodes in the posterior triangle of the neck (cervical lymphadenopathy) is indicative of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice.
Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is extremely radiosensitive, hence treatment of local and regional disease is invariably radiotherapy.

questions.text: A young boxer receives a blow near the eye during a boxing match. He presents to the ER with hematoma around eye, CT scan is shown below. Identify the radiological sign shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Tear-drop sign

The given CT image dipicts ‘tear-drop’ sign and suggests a blowout fracture.
Tear-drop/hanging drop sign is characteristic of an orbital “blow-out” fracture, which represents the orbital contents herniating through the floor of the orbit into the maxillary antrum. The most useful projection for detecting an orbital floor fracture is Water’s view.

questions.text: A child was eating a custard apple when a seed suddenly became lodged in the throat, causing coughing and respiratory distress. On palpation, a knob-like structure was felt, and auscultation revealed an audible thud. What is the likely location of the obstruction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Trachea
A history of cough, respiratory distress, a palpable knob and on auscultation, an audible thud in a child suggests a foreign body lodged in the trachea.
The classical signs associated with tracheal foreign bodies:
(1)    Asthmatoid wheeze 
(2)    audible slap produced from foreign body contact with the trachea
      (3) palpable thud over the trachea
The next step in managing this patient is to obtain a chest X-ray, followed by bronchoscopic removal of the foreign body.

questions.text: A patient presents with nasal obstruction and merciful anosmia. Greenish-black crusts were found in the nasal cavity of a patient. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Atrophic rhinitis

The presence of merciful anosmia and greenish-black crusts in the nasal cavity points to a diagnosis of atrophic rhinitis.
Atrophic rhinitis is a chronic inflammation of the nose characterized by atrophy of nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. The exact etiology of this condition is not known. It is more common in females and starts around puberty.
Clinically patients present with nasal obstruction, foul odor, and merciful anosmia. Merciful anosmia is when the patient has marked anosmia and is unable to smell the foul odor coming from their nose.

questions.text: Identify the type of tympanoplasty shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Type 3

The columella tympanoplasty is type 3 as per the Wullstein’s classification of tympanoplasty.
While performing this procedure, the diseased ear would have already lost the malleus and incus, and hence the graft is placed over the stapes superstructure. Therefore, it is also called myringostapediopexy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with difficulty in hearing. A pure-tone audiogram was obtained, which is shown below. What is the interpretation of this audiogram?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Left-sided mixed hearing loss

The audiogram indicates left-sided mixed hearing loss. The blue color represents the left ear, with bone conduction (BC) thresholds above 25 dB, indicating sensorineural impairment. Air conduction (AC) thresholds are also elevated above 15 dB, suggesting abnormal AC. The presence of both abnormal AC and BC, along with an air-bone gap, confirms mixed hearing loss, which involves both conductive and sensorineural pathways. This type of hearing loss is commonly seen in conditions like chronic suppurative otitis media and otosclerosis.

questions.text: The following sign is seen in a patient presenting with rhinorrhea following a skull base fracture. Identify the sign.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Double Target Sign

The given image shows the Double target sign or Halo sign or Target sign seen in CSF rhinorrhoea and suggests basal skull fracture due to trauma in this case.
Double target sign is seen patients with CSF rhinorrhea. The nasal discharge in a patient with CSF rhinorrhea after head trauma is mixed with blood. When this discharge is collected on a filter paper, it shows a double target sign with a central red spot and a peripheral lighter halo.

questions.text: What is the important area depicted in the given image by red arrow?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ostiomeatal complex

The image above shows the computed tomography (CT) scan of the ostiomeatal complex.
The following image gives an explanation of these structures.
The coronal CT scan demonstrates key components of the ostiomeatal unit:
1. Ethmoid bulla, indicated by a white arrow
2. Maxillary sinus ostium, marked by a white arrowhead
3. Middle meatus, denoted by asterisks
4. Uncinate process, shown by a hollow arrow
5. Hiatus semilunaris (the space between uncinate process and ethmoid bulla), marked by a white circle
6. Ethmoid infundibulum, traced by a dashed line

questions.text: Which of the following conditions shown in the given CT is associated with the Holman-Miller sign?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Juvenile nasopharnygeal angiofibroma

The given CT showing the Holman-Miller sign is associated with nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.
Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign but locally invasive tumor predominant in adolescent males aged 10-20 years. It arises from the posterior part of the nasal cavity, close to the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen. These patients have a hamartomatous nidus of vascular tissue in the nasopharynx that grows to form angiofibroma under the influence of testosterone. Therefore, it is thought to be testosterone-dependent.

questions.text:
A patient presented with nasal congestion and upon examination, nasal polyps were observed. A coronal CT scan finding of the patient is given below. Which of the following sinus drainage pathways is likely to be affected?
CT-Computed Tomography
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Maxillary

In this patient with rhinosinusitis and nasal polyps, the CT scan indicates that the maxillary sinus is likely affected, as evidenced by the presence of a polyp in this sinus.
Antrochoanal polyp is a type of non-neoplastic nasal polypoidal masses of edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. It arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum near its accessory ostium, comes out of it, and grows in the choana and nasal cavity. It is usually single and unilateral which are more commonly seen in children and young adults.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Buccopharyngeal Fascia

The structure marked in the given image is the buccopharyngeal fascia.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child was eating peanuts when he suddenly developed respiratory distress, cough, and was unable to speak. What is the initial treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Perform Heimlich maneuver

In a choking child (more than 1 year old) or an adult, the first step to be done is to perform Heimlich maneuver, which involves delivering abdominal thrusts.
The rescuer should stand or kneel behind the patient and wrap his arms around the patient’s waist. A fist is made with one hand and using the other hand, the fist is driven into the patient’s abdomen with a rapid, forceful upward thrust so as to dislodge the foreign body. This is continued until the foreign body is expelled or if the patient becomes unresponsive.

questions.text: A child presents with the findings shown in the image below. Which structure is most likely involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cranial nerve 7

The given clinical findings are suggestive of Bell’s palsy which is a paralysis of the facial nerve. Bell’s palsy is an idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis affecting the same side of the face, causing inability to close the eye (which turns up with Bell’s phenomenon), facial asymmetry, drooling, noise intolerance, and loss of taste.

choices.text: Drug-drug interaction between TB and HIV medications
Development of drug resistance to anti-tubercular drugs
Development of drug resistance to ART

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with tuberculosis and HIV was started on both anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) and antiretroviral therapy (ART). After 2 months, the patient experienced a deterioration in his health. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Immunological changes in the body

In HIV/TB patients on ATT and ART, worsening after treatment suggests IRIS, a paradoxical inflammation due to immune recovery, common in those with low CD4 counts or untreated infections.

questions.text: An HIV-positive man presents with a high-grade fever. Examination reveals a positive Kernig’s sign. CSF shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes. A diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is made. What is the appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Liposomal armphotericin B+ flucytosine

Cryptococcal meningitis, common in AIDS with CD4 <100, presents as subacute meningoencephalitis with elevated CSF pressure, modest WBC/protein, and low glucose. Diagnosis is by CSF India ink stain or cryptococcal antigen test. Treatment is liposomal amphotericin B plus flucytosine.

questions.text: A patient visits the neurology clinic with trouble transitioning between movements and exhibits involuntary hand movements during rapid alternating tasks, such as finger tapping. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Dysdiadochokinesis

The patient has difficulty switching from one movement to another which is suggestive of Dysdiadochokinesia. It is the inability to perform rapid alternate movements.
It is a clinical manifestation of cerebellar dysfunction and is most evident when strength and sensation are intact. Focal lesions in the nervous system may produce highly asymmetric dysdiadochokinesia.

choices.text: Serum albumin ascites gradient of greater than 1.1 g/dL
Serum albumin ascites gradient of less than 1.1 g/dL
Ascitic protein level less than 2.5 g/dL suggests damage to hepatic sinusoids

questions.text: A patient with liver cirrhosis presents with breathing difficulty due to massive ascites. Which is an incorrect statement about this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Serum albumin ascites gradient of less than 1.1 g/dL

The incorrect statement in the given clinical scenario of a patient with liver cirrhosis presenting with breathing difficulty due to massive ascites is a Serum albumin ascites gradient of less than 1.1.

SAAG greater than 1.1 g/dl and ascitic protein less than 2.5 g/dl are seen in ascites due to cirrhosis.

choices.text: Supranuclear facial palsy on the left side
Infranuclear facial palsy on the left side
Supranuclear facial palsy on the right side
Infranuclear facial palsy on the right side

questions.text: A young male presents with left-sided facial weakness. On examination, the patient is able to wrinkle his forehead and is able to close the right eye partially, and his mouth deviates towards the right side when smiling. Based on these findings, which of the following statements best describes the type and location of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Supranuclear facial palsy on the right side

The given clinical scenario of a young male presenting with weakness of the lower half of the left side of his face and presence of wrinkling on the forehead and normal eyelid closure indicates an upper motor neuron lesion (UMN). The most appropriate diagnosis is supranuclear facial palsy on the right side.
In facial palsy, the angle of the mouth deviates towards the normal side. In this patient, since the mouth deviates towards the right, the left facial nerve is affected.

questions.text: The patient presents with headache, vomiting and nuchal rigidity. Guarded LP was done and shows turbid CSF. Microscopy shows 90% PMN cells with sugar of 40 mg/dL and protein of 200 mg/dl. Which is correct about the management of this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ceftriaxone plus vancomycin

The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with headache, vomiting, and nuchal rigidity and a guarded lumbar puncture revealing turbid CSF with 90% PMN cells, a sugar level of 40 mg/dL, and protein of 200 mg/dL is suggestive of bacterial meningitis and the appropriate management includes treatment with ceftriaxone plus vancomycin.
The most common cause of meningitis in adults over 20 years of age is Streptococcus pneumoniae.

questions.text: A patient has been diagnosed with mitral stenosis. What is the determinant of the severity of mitral stenosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

S2-opening snap gap

The more severe the thickening, the earlier the opening snap occurs in diastole. Hence, decreased intervals between S2 and opening snap (OS) indicate increased stenosis severity.
The auscultatory findings which are suggestive of increased severity of murmur are:
- Decreased interval between S2/ A2 and opening snap(OS).
- Increased duration of the diastolic murmur.

questions.text: A boy comes with the history of passing of black urine during the night time, and on further investigation, CD55 and CD59 markers were negative. Which condition is the boy most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

PNH

The boy likely has Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH), an acquired hemolytic anemia caused by X-linked PIG-A gene mutation, leading to GPI deficiency. This results in lack of protective proteins CD55 and CD59, making red blood cells vulnerable to complement-mediated intravascular hemolysis and causing hemoglobinuria.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child is noted to have muscle weakness. Vitals Pulse: 80/min, BP 70/50 mm Hg. The workup shows metabolic alkalosis with hypokalaemia and hypomagnesemia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Gitelman syndrome

The given clinical scenario of a 6-month-old child presenting with muscle weakness with a pulse of 80/min and BP 70/50 mm Hg (hypotension) with metabolic alkalosis, hypokalaemia and hypomagnesemia is suggestive of Gitelman syndrome.
Gitelman syndrome occurs due to a mutation of Na+/Cl cotransporter in the distal collecting tubule (DCT). The resulting impairment of the tubular transport leads to the following features:
- Mild natriuresis with normal-low BP.
- Increased renin and aldosterone.
- Hypokalemia.
- Metabolic alkalosis.
- Hypercalcemia and hypocalciuria.
- Hypomagnesemia.
The clinical features of this condition are similar to the effects of thiazide diuretics.

questions.text: The INR ratio recommended for the administration of warfarin in patients with mechanical heart valves is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

2.5-3.5

The INR ratio recommended for the administration of warfarin in patients with mechanical heart valves is around 2.5-3.5.
Prothrombin time is sensitive to the reduction in levels of prothrombin, factor VII, and factor X. The test is performed by adding thromboplastin, which is a reagent containing tissue factor, phospholipid and calcium to citrated plasma and determining the time to clot formation.

questions.text: A patient with a history of Infect”on two weeks ago developed progressively ascending, bilaterally symmetric flaccid weakness in the lower limbs, which later involved the upper limbs. Examination reveals absent spinal cord reflexes. Based on the given findings, what could be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy

The given clinical scenario of a patient with a history of infection two weeks ago who develops progressively ascending, bilaterally symmetric flaccid weakness in the lower limbs, later affecting the upper limbs and on examination absent spinal cord reflexes are seen. These findings suggest a likely diagnosis of Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP).
AIDP is the most common type of Guillain-Barre syndrome(GBS). GBS is usually associated with a history of upper respiratory infection (URI) or acute gastroenteritis (AGE) 1-3 weeks prior. The causative organisms may be Campylobacter jejuni, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, and Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

questions.text: A patient has visual disturbance a”d pain abdomen after drinking from a local shop. Which metabolite is responsible for that?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Formic acid

The above clinical scenario is suggestive of methanol toxicity, and the metabolite responsible is formic acid.
Methanol poisoning is caused by to ingestion of illicit liquor which contains ethanol adulterated with methanol. Methanol is metabolized to formaldehyde and formic acid by alcohol and aldehyde dehydrogenases, respectively. The metabolites of methanol are responsible for the toxic effects.
Clinically, patients present with headache, vomiting, abdomen pain, uneasiness, confusion, delirium, and coma. Formic acid specifically damages the retina and optic nerve and results in blurring of vision and blindness.
Elevated levels of formic acid and other organic acids result in metabolic acidosis in arterial blood gas analysis(ABG).

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with complaints of breathlessness and is diagnosed with a Pancoast tumor. Which of the following findings is not typically associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Exophthalmus

Pancoast syndrome is associated with Horner’s syndrome, resulting in ptosis, miosis and anhidrosis. It is not associated with exophthalmus.
Horner syndrome, or oculosympathetic paresis, results from a lesion along the sympathetic pathway to the head, eye, and neck. It presents with ptosis due to Müller’s muscle weakness, miosis causing anisocoria (more prominent in dim light), ipsilateral anhidrosis, heterochromia (lighter iris in congenital or longstanding cases), and enophthalmos.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with anasarca is found to have proteinuria >4g/day, oedema and hypoalbuminemia, which is consistent with nephrotic syndrome. What is the recommended management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Steroids

The clinical picture and investigations are highly suggestive of minimal change disease in nephrotic syndrome and the initial treatment of choice is with steroids.
Minimal change nephrotic syndrome is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome. It is seen in ages 2-6 years with a clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome, that is, heavy proteinuria, oedema, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia. They may be asymptomatic or can present with peripheral oedema. Renal biopsy is not required for confirmation and treatment can be initiated if the child fits the standard clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome.
They show excellent response to steroid therapy with prednisone or prednisolone. A daily dose of 2mg/kg (max 60mg) for 6 weeks followed by an alternate dose of 1.5mg/kg (max 40mg) for the next 6-8 weeks is recommended.

choices.text: Pleural protein ratio less than 0.5 of serum protein
Pleural LDH less than 2/3rd of serum LDH
Pleural LDH less than 0.6 of serum LDH

questions.text: A patient with a history of pneumonia develops pleural effusion. What is the expected finding in the pleural fluid analysis for parapneumonic effusion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pleural pH less than 7.2

In the above clinical scenario of a patient with a history of pneumonia who develops a pleural effusion, the expected finding in the pleural fluid analysis for parapneumonic effusion is pleural pH less than 7.2.
Pleural effusion refers to the pathological accumulation of fluid in the pleural space due to:
- excess fluid formation from the interstitial spaces of the lung, parietal pleura or peritoneal cavity
- decreased fluid removal by the lymphatics
Pleural effusion may present with:
- dyspnea
- pleuritic pain
- dry cough
- associated symptoms like fever, weight loss, oedema, and ascites depending on the aetiology.

choices.text: Normal PR and prolonged RR interval
Prolonged PR and normal RR interval
Short PR and normal RR interval

questions.text: What is correct about first-degree heart block?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Prolonged PR and normal RR interval

The correct statement about the first-degree heart block is the ECG shows prolonged PR and normal RR interval.
First-degree heart block is characterized by a fixed, prolonged PR interval without any dropped beats. It indicates a delay in conduction through the AV node, but all atrial impulses still reach the ventricles. It is most often asymptomatic. Canon waves are observed in JVP. It carries a very good prognosis and no treatment is needed.
A heart block is caused by an interruption of impulse conduction within the conducting system of the heart. It may be sinoatrial, atrioventricular, or intraventricular. Atrioventricular blocks are further divided into type I, type II and type III blocks. The type II blocks are subdivided into Mobitz type I and Mobitz type II blocks.

questions.text: Graham Steell murmur is heard in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pulmonary regurgitation

Graham Steell murmur is the early to mid-diastolic murmur heard in pulmonary regurgitation.
Graham Steell murmur is a high-pitched murmur heard best at the left second intercostal space and is often louder with inspiration. This murmur occurs due to pulmonary regurgitation, which in this case, is secondary to pulmonary hypertension. It can also be seen in patients with COPD due to the development of cor pulmonale leading to pulmonic hypertension.

questions.text: An obese patient presented with pain in the right hypochondrium. He has a history of unhealthy food consumption. On examination, the liver was palpable below the costal margin. On USG, grade 2 fatty liver was diagnosed. What will be the initial management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Reduce weight and lifestyle changes

In this clinical scenario, an obese patient presents with right hypochondrial pain and a history of poor dietary habits.
Examination reveals a palpable liver, and ultrasound confirms Grade 2 fatty liver, suggesting Non-Alcoholic Steatohepatitis (NASH). The initial management involves weight reduction and lifestyle modifications, including a healthier diet and regular physical activity.
Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is associated with diabetes and obesity. The fatty change may also be caused by the effect of toxins (including certain medications), protein malnutrition, dyslipidemia, and anoxia. Bleomycin, Methotrexate, Doxycycline, and L-asparaginase are other drugs causing hepatic steatosis.

questions.text:
A child with short stature and developmental delay comes to your clinic. On investigation, low calcium, high phosphate and very high PTH are found. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
PTH-Parathyroid hormone
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pseudohypoparathyroidism
Based on the given clinical scenario of a child with short stature and developmental delay with low Calcium, high Phosphate and very high PTH, the most likely diagnosis is Pseudohypoparathyroidism (PHP)
Pseudohypoparathyroidism (PHP) Is a condition where the body is resistant to parathyroid hormone (PTH) despite its excessive production. This leads to low calcium, high phosphate, and very high PTH, as the kidneys and bones do not respond to PTH signals. The associated short stature and developmental delay are characteristic of Albright’s hereditary osteodystrophy (AHO), a subtype of PHP.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient who suffers from prinzmetal angina requires a formulation of nitroglycerine which has the most rapid onset of action. Which of the following formulations of nitroglycerin can be administered to the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sublingual spray
The sublingual route of administration has a very rapid onset of action (1-3 mins). The onset of action is more rapid when administered as a spray when compared to a tablet.
The sublingual route is used for the termination of attacks. Oral extended-release capsule and transdermal patch are used for prophylaxis. The onset of action is approximately ≥60 min.
Topical nitroglycerine ointment can be used to provide symptomatic relief in patients with anal fissures.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman complains of fatigue, dry skin and cold intolerance since 2 weeks. She was started on amiodarone 1 month ago for persistent atrial fibrillation. Tests show high TSH (15 mU/I) and low free T4 levels. How would you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Supplement levothyroxine

Thyroxine supplementation is indicated for amiodarone induced hypothyroidism which is characterized by symptoms of hypothyroidism (fatigue, dry skin, cold intolerance) and lab findings (elevated TSH, reduced free T4) following amiodarone use.
Amiodarone-induced hypothyroidism (AIH) can occur shortly after (as early as 2 weeks) amiodarone use due to iodine induced thyroid suppression (Wolff Chaikoff effect). It is characterized by clinical features of hypothyroidism and lab findings of elevated TSH and reduced free T4. It occurs more frequently in women and those with positive thyroid peroxidase antibodies. It is managed by thyroxine supplementation, without the need to discontinue amiodarone.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding intrinsic acute kidney injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

BUN:Creatinine < 20:1

The correct statement regarding intrinsic acute kidney injury is BUN: Creatinine < 20:1
AKI (acute kidney injury) is defined as a decline in kidney function within 7 days, resulting in the accumulation of nitrogenous waste and other toxic metabolites usually excreted in the urine. It includes a variety of conditions that share some common features such as elevated creatinine levels and reduced urine output. It is broadly divided into three categories:
- Prerenal azotemia
- Intrinsic parenchymal disease
- Postrenal obstruction

questions.text: Chvostek’s sign is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hypocalcemia

The Chvostek’s sign is seen in Hypocalcemia.
Chvostek’s sign is a clinical indicator of hypocalcemia, seen in conditions like hypoparathyroidism and vitamin D deficiency. It is elicited by gently tapping the facial nerve just anterior to the ear, which triggers involuntary twitching of the facial muscles, particularly around the mouth and eye.

questions.text: The patient is admitted with low urine output, and lab reports show BUN: 140 mg/dL, serum creatinine: 8.0 mg/dL, and 2+ protein on urine dipstick. Which of the following is most useful for distinguishing acute kidney injury (AKI) from chronic kidney disease (CKD)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Creatinine clearance

In a patient admitted with low urine output, BUN of 140 mg/dL, serum creatinine of 8.0 mg/dL, and 2+ protein on urine dipstick, the most useful criterion for differentiating acute kidney injury (AKI) from chronic kidney disease (CKD) is creatinine clearance.
Acute kidney injury (AKI) is defined as an increase in serum creatinine by 1.5 times of baseline value over 7 days.
Acute kidney injury is defined as an abrupt (within hours) decrease in kidney function, which encompasses both injury (structural damage) and impairment (loss of function). It is characterized by abrupt deterioration in kidney function, manifested by an increase in serum creatinine level with or without reduced urine output.

questions.text: A young female presents with vomiting episodes for the past few days. Interpret the ABG report of pH: 7.53, pCO2 48 mm Hg and HCO3: 33 meq/L.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Metabolic alkalosis

This ABG pattern is consistent with metabolic alkalosis secondary to prolonged vomiting, leading to the loss of hydrogen ions (H+) and chloride (Cl-) from gastric secretions.
The primary disturbance Is metabolic alkalosis (high HCO₃-and elevated pH). This is likely caused by excessive vomiting, which leads to loss of gastric acid (HCI), increasing bicarbonate levels.

choices.text: Continue metformin at the same dose

questions.text: A patient with diabetes mellitus has a fasting blood sugar of 180 mg/dL and HbA1c of 8.5%. The treatment was started on Tab metformin 500mg, and his blood sugar has come down to 140 mg/dL, but his HbA1c remains above 7.3%. What is the next step In management?”
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Increase Tab Metformin to 1000mg

The next step in management is increasing the dose of metformin to 1000mg.
Increasing the dose of metformin is the first step in improving the glycemic control of patients with type 2 diabetes whose HbA1c levels are > 6.5% while receiving a dose of less than 2000 mg daily which is the maximum tolerable dose by which we can benefit from increasing dose, confirming that the efficacy of metformin is dependent upon dosage.
According to American Diabetes Association (ADA) Standards of Medical Care in Diabetes, Metformin is the preferred first line therapeutic agent for type 2 Diabetes unless contraindicated or not tolerated by the patient. Othe” hypoglycemic agents are added considering patient preferences, hypoglycemia risk and other comorbidities.

questions.text: A patient present” with a unilateral throbbing headache in the temporal region and light sensitivity associated with photophobia, nausea and vomiting. She reports that each episode lasts for a maximum of 24 hours, which was relieved by giving triptans. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Migraine

The clinical picture of throbbing unilateral headache, light sensitivity associated with photophobia, nausea and vomiting and responsiveness to triptans indicates a diagnosis of migraine.
Migraine is the second most common cause of headaches, after tension headaches. It is characterized by unilateral and throbbing headaches of moderate to severe intensity. Other features of migraine include deep-seated pain and sensitivity to environmental and sensory stimuli. The headache can be triggered by glares, bright lights, sounds, hunger, stress, physical exertion, hormonal fluctuations during menses, lack of or excess sleep, or alcohol.

questions.text: A patient presents with fatigue and chronic diarrhea for 4 months. Endoscopy reveals several ulcers in the gastric antrum and the descending duodenum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Zollinger-Ellison syndrome

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of gastrinoma Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.
Zollinger Ellison Syndrome (ZES)/Gastrinoma is a neuroendocrinal tumour characterized by hypersecretion of gastrin resulting in gastrointestinal tract ulcers. It occurs more commonly in a sporadic pattern but can be associated with MEN-1 (multiple endocrine neoplasia-1) syndromes in the familial pattern. Gastrinoma is most commonly located in the gastrinoma triangle (Passaro’s triangle) bounded by the lines connecting the:
- cystic duct
- the junction between the second and third parts of the duodenum
- the junction between the neck and body of the pancreas

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with respiratory difficulty and a history of chronic smoking for the last 30 years. Pulmonary function testing shows a decrease in FEV1% and FEV1/FVC ratio. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

COPD

The given clinical scenario including symptoms of respiratory difficulty and history of chronic smoking along with pulmonary function testing revealing a reduced FEV1% and FEV1/FVC ratio is indicative of an obstructive disorder -Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD).
These values are measured as a part of the pulmonary function test known as spirometry. At a given lung volume, when a person inhales to the total lung capacity and exhales as hard and completely as possible, the volume of expired air is recorded as forced vital capacity (FVC), and the volume of air expired in the first second is called the forced expiratory volume (FEV1).

questions.text: A patient presents with progressive increase in shortness of breath. On examination, left parasternal heave is noted. On auscultation, a systolic murmur is heard. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pulmonary stenosis

The patient presents with worsening shortness of breath, and examination reveals a left parasternal heave and a systolic murmur on auscultation, pointing to the diagnosis of pulmonary stenosis.
Pulmonary stenosis is a congenital heart defect where there is a narrowing of the pulmonary valve or the area just below the valve, obstructing blood flow from the right ventricle to the lungs. This leads to increased pressure in the right ventricle, causing it to work harder to pump blood. The condition may range from mild to severe and can result in symptoms like shortness of breath, fatigue, and cyanosis in severe cases.

questions.text: A 47-year-old hypertensive woman came to your clinic complaining of bone pain. She has a history of recurrent renal stones. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Thiazide diuretics

Given the clinical picture of a 47-year-old hypertensive woman with bone pain and recurrent renal stones, the most likely diagnosis is hyperparathyroidism (often primary hyperparathyroidism) and the most appropriate management for the given condition is thiazide diuretics.
Thiazides reduce calcium excretion in the urine, which can help prevent the formation of kidney stones in hyperparathyroidism and help manage the hypercalcemia associated with it.

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic man, after attending a party, was brought to the hospital by his relative with complaints of seeing snakes crawling in his room and inability to recognise his family members. He reports his last alcohol intake was 48 hours ago. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Delirium tremens

The clinical scenario describes a 45-year-old chronic alcoholic man who, after attending a party, was brought to the hospital by his relative due to hallucinations of snakes crawling in his room and an inability to recognize his family members. He mentions that his last alcohol consumption was 48 hours ago. The most probable diagnosis is delirium tremens.
Delirium tremens is a medical emergency that occurs during alcohol withdrawal. It is an acute condition and usually develops within 72 hours after the last drink. It has symptoms of both delirium and alcohol withdrawal.

questions.text: A young lady presents with recent-onset palpitations and dizziness. Her ECG shows absent P waves and an irregularly irregular RR interval. Her pulse rate is 140 bpm and BP is 80/60 mmHg. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Synchronized cardioversion

In this patient with recent palpitations, dizziness, and ECG showing irregularly irregular rhythm with no P waves (atrial fibrillation), urgent synchronized cardioversion is indicated due to hypotension. Rate control with IV beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers (verapamil or diltiazem) is also important, along with subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin to reduce thromboembolism risk.

questions.text: The patient came to the ER with pain on the left side of the chest radiating to the left arm and shoulder for the last 40 minutes. ECG shows ST depression in precordial leads. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Low dose aspirin + clopidogrel

The given clinical scenario of a patient coming to the ER with pain on the left side of the chest radiating to the left arm and shoulder for the last 40 minutes. ECG showing ST depression in precordial leads is suggestive of NSTEMI (Non-ST elevation Myocardial infarction) and the next best step in management is low-dose aspirin with clopidogrel.

questions.text: The patient came to the ER with pain on the left side of the chest radiating to the left arm and shoulder following exercise. The pain subsided after some time. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

ECG

The given clinical scenario of a patient coming to the ER with pain on the left side of the chest radiating to the left arm and shoulder can be suggestive of ACS (Acute Coronary Syndrome), and the next best step in management is doing an ECG.
Acute coronary syndromes (ACS) includes:
- Unstable angina(UA)
- Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI)
- ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)

The diagnosis of ACS can be based on the ECG findings-:
STEMI- Features of MI on ECG:
ST-segment elevation: Zone of injury
T wave inversions
Deep Q waves: late sign to develop
New left bundle branch block (LBBB)

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a known case of rheumatic heart disease presents with SOB. On examination, hyperdynamic precordium is noted with a water hammer pulse, and a pistol shot sound over femoral arteries is heard. Auscultation shows pan systolic murmur and early diastolic murmur. Which is the predominant valvular lesion shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Aortic regurgitation

The predominant valvular lesion is aortic regurgitation. The water hammer pulse and pistol shot sounds over the femoral arteries suggest high-pressure blood flow due to aortic insufficiency. The pan systolic murmur indicates mitral regurgitation, while the early diastolic murmur is characteristic of aortic regurgitation, often seen in rheumatic heart disease.

Aortic regurgitation (AR) is a valvular disease of the aortic valve caused by primary valve disease, aortic root disease or their combination.

questions.text: A 4-month-old child was brought to the hospital with an abdominal lesion, as shown in the image. What is the appropriate management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Observation

Infantile hemangiomas often involute by age 5-7, so observation is usually enough. Growth peaks before 1 year, then involution begins. Treatment is needed for complications like ulceration or if the lesion affects vital functions, such as vision.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with painful genital ulcers on vulva accompanied by bilateral lymphadenopathy. She has a history of multiple partners over the years. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Chancroid

Chancroid is an STI caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, presenting with painful genital ulcers and swollen, tender inguinal lymph nodes that may form buboes. The ulcers can spread and merge through auto-inoculation, earning the name “kissing ulcers.”

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady diagnosed with breast carcinoma. Who underwent chemotherapy presents with hair loss after 3 weeks. What is this pattern of hair loss known as?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Anagen effluvium

Anagen effluvium arises from the disruption of the anagen phase of the hair cycle, primarily occurring after chemotherapy.
It is due to the disruption of the anagen or proliferating phase of the hair cycle. Hair shedding typically occurs within 1-3 weeks and it is complete within 1-2 months after the initiation of chemotherapy.

questions.text: The given picture shows lesions found on the glans penis and pigmentation in the chin and oral cavity. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lichen Sclerosis

White atrophic patches on the glans penis along with extragenital manifestations like hyperpigmentation of the face and oral mucosa are suggestive of Lichen Sclerosis.
Lichen sclerosus is a chronic inflammatory condition that affects the anogenital area. On the glans penis, it presents as white, atrophic patches that can become porcelain-white in appearance. The condition often shows extragenital manifestations, particularly hyperpigmentation in areas like the face and oral cavity. The disease process involves dermal sclerosis and atrophy of the epidermis, leading to characteristic whitish patches.

questions.text: A patient presents with multiple nodulocystic lesions on the face. Which among the following is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Isotretinoin

The likely diagnosis in this patient is nodular acne, and the preferred treatment is oral isotretinoin. Isotretinoin is a systemic retinoid used for severe acne, but it commonly causes side effects such as dry lips (cheilitis), dry skin (xerosis), dry mouth (xerostomia), dry nose, and increased sun sensitivity. It is contraindicated in pregnant women or those who may become pregnant due to its teratogenic potential.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with following finding. Which of the following clinical tests will aid in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Grattage Test

The image shows silvery, scaly plaques typical of psoriasis. The scratch (Auspitz) test reveals pinpoint bleeding when scales are scraped, due to dilated capillaries in elongated dermal papillae. While characteristic, Auspitz sign is not highly sensitive or specific for psoriasis.

questions.text: A non-smoker patient with a history of cardiac disease suddenly develops chest pain and breathlessness. An X-ray is performed and given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cardiogenic pulmonary edema

Chest X-ray showing interstitial markings, vascular redistribution, and butterfly-shaped alveolar edema indicates pulmonary edema. Causes include severe hypertension, MI, or heart failure exacerbation, often triggered by medication non-compliance, salt intake, or arrhythmias. Presents with severe dyspnea, pink frothy sputum, diaphoresis, cyanosis, and crackles. Management includes diuretics, nitrates, and morphine to reduce preload; nitrates can be given sublingually or IV if needed.

questions.text: A patient presents with backache, night sweats, an evening increase in temperature, and unintentional weight loss. Laboratory tests reveal an increase in CRP and ESR levels. An MRI is provided below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pott’s spine

Pott’s spine (tuberculous spondylitis) shows a well-defined vertebral lesion with T1 hypointensity and T2 iso-hypointensity on MRI. It involves the vertebral bodies and discs via hematogenous spread, causing slow vertebral collapse, kyphotic deformity, and possible spinal cord compression, with symptoms like back pain and weakness.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary use of the given imaging modality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Staging of esophageal cancer

Endoscopic ultrasound stages esophageal carcinoma, which is more common in men. Risk factors include tobacco and alcohol. The main types are squamous cell (upper third) and adenocarcinoma (lower third), with adenocarcinoma incidence rising.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man is rushed to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, abdominal distension, and obstipation. His erect X-ray abdomen is as shown. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Sigmoid volvulus

The given clinical scenario of a 64-year-old man with severe abdominal pain, abdominal disternision, and obstipation along with the radiograph showing the coffee bean sign is likely to be sigmoid volvulus.

questions.text: A female patient presents with difficulty ingesting liquids more than solids. What is the most likely characteristic finding on imaging?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Rat tail appearance

Achalasia is a motility disorder with impaired LES relaxation and absent peristalsis, causing difficulty swallowing liquids more than solids and a characteristic "Rat tail" sign on imaging.

questions.text: A patient with a history of breast cancer underwent tele cobalt-60 radiotherapy. She now presents with respiratory distress, and imaging shows bilateral perihilar ground glass opacities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Radiation pneumonitis

Radiation pneumonitis is an inflammation of the lungs after radiotherapy, common in breast, lung, or lymphoma patients. It occurs weeks to months post-treatment, causing cough, fever, chest pain, and shortness of breath. CT shows ground-glass opacities and consolidation in the radiation field due to alveolar and capillary damage.

questions.text: Which of the following dosage regimens for the adult leprosy treatment kit is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Rifampicin 450 mg weekly

The WHO recommends 600 mg rifampicin monthly for leprosy, not 450 mg weekly. Paucibacillary leprosy is treated with 600 mg rifampicin and dapsone for 6 months, while multibacillary leprosy includes rifampicin, clofazimine, and dapsone for 12 months to kill bacteria and prevent resistance.

questions.text: National Deworming Day is observed on
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

10th February and 10th August

National Deworming Day is observed in India on February 10th and August 10th to address parasitic worm infections, especially in children aged 1 to 19. This biannual initiative aims to reduce intestinal worm prevalence and enhance children's health and nutrition, particularly in rural and underserved communities, as part of the government's broader health improvement efforts.

questions.text: The government pasted public awareness posters in public places. What type of communication method does this approach represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Mass approach
The mass approach in communication involves spreading information to large audiences through posters, media, and social platforms. It aims to raise awareness and promote positive behavior on social, health, or safety issues efficiently.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is contraindicated in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Varicella

Varicella vaccine is contraindicated in pregnant women as it is a live vaccine.
Live attenuated vaccines are prepared from organisms that have lost their capacity to induce full-blown disease but retain their immunogenicity and are contraindicated in pregnancy unless the risk of infection exceeds the risk of harm to the fetus.
Varicella, Mumps, BCG, Measles and Rubella vaccines are examples of live attenuated vaccines.

questions.text: According to the latest 2024 updates in NIS, what are the correct fractional doses of IPV vaccines?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

6 weeks, 14 weeks and 9 months

According to the latest 2024 updates in NIS, the correct fractional doses of IPV vaccines is given at 6 weeks, 14 weeks and 9 months.
