In January 2023, India’s NIS added a third fractional IPV dose at 9 months. The schedule includes three intradermal doses: at 6 weeks, 14 weeks, and 9 months, each of 0.1 ml, to boost immunity against poliovirus.

questions.text: What is it called when a tour guide leads a group of tourists as they follow him through various attractions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Herd
When a tourist guide directs a group of people who closely follow him at different tourist sites, it is referred to as herd behaviour.
A herd is a group of animals or people moving together, often following a leader or collective behaviour. In tourism, herd behaviour refers to a group of tourists following a guide, making collective decisions rather than acting independently.

questions.text: A handwashing awareness session was conducted in a community. The correct sequence of events here is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Awareness > interest > evaluation > adoption

The correct sequence of events in this health awareness session is: awareness > interest > evaluation > adoption.
Awareness: The individual learns about the innovation but pays little attention.
Interest: The person seeks more information about the product’s features, risks, and availability.
Evaluation: The consumer compares the innovation with existing products to assess its worth.
Adoption: If satisfied during trial, the consumer decides to purchase and use the product.

questions.text: A group of 400 low birth weight (LBW) babies and 200 normal birth weight babies were monitored from birth until one year of age to assess the development of protein-energy malnutrition, with data collected at regular intervals throughout the study. What type of study does this represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cohort Study

The scenario describes a cohort study, which groups participants by birth weight (exposure) and follows them over time to observe malnutrition (outcome). It is a prospective, longitudinal study that reliably links cause and effect.

questions.text: What is the particle size of dust particles involved in pneumoconiosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

0.5 to 3 microns
Inhalation of dust particles in the size range of 0.5 to 3 microns is considered to be the most dangerous. It can lead to various occupational lung diseases called Pneumoconiosis.

questions.text: Mr. X enlisted in the Navy in 1997, married Y in 1999, and welcomed their first child, V, in 2002, followed by their second child, M, in 2009. After retiring in 2020 and starting a job at SBI, his parents moved in to live with his family. Which of the following statements accurately describes this family?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

2002- Extension

The correct answer is 2002-Extension.

The extension phase begins with the birth of the first child, which is 2002 in this scenario.

A family is a group of biologically related individuals living together under the same roof and eating from a common kitchen. It is the primary and basic unit of all societies.

choices.text: Ministry of Health and Family Welfare

questions.text: Which ministry is the main authority for disaster management in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ministry of Home Affairs

The Ministry of Home Affairs is the nodal ministry for disaster management in India.
The National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA), headed by the Prime Minister of India, is the apex body for Disaster Management in India. The Indian Meteorological Department plays a role in the mitigation of disaster and its preparedness.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the management of HIV patient with multiple dog bites?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Rabies vaccine + immunoglobuin+ wound management

In the given scenario, an HIV patient with multiple dog bites falls under Category 3 for rabies vaccination and should receive rabies vaccine, immunoglobulin, and proper wound care.
Rabies is a fatal viral disease transmitted through the bite or scratch of an infected animal, primarily dogs. Rabies vaccination is the most effective way to prevent the disease after exposure.
The post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) regimen includes thorough wound cleaning, administration of the rabies vaccine, and in severe cases (Category 3 exposure), rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) for immediate virus neutralization. The rabies vaccine is administered in a series of intramuscular or intradermal doses, following schedules like the Essen regimen (0, 3, 7, 14, and 28 days) or the Zagreb regimen (0, 7, and 21 days). Immediate treatment is crucial, as rabies is nearly 100% fatal once symptoms appear.

questions.text: An HIV patient presented with bouts of cough and fever. What is the selective medium used for investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Lowenstein-Jenson medium

A patient with HIV presenting with cough and fever likely has tuberculosis. Lowenstein-Jensen medium is a specialized culture medium for Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It contains malachite green, which inhibits other bacteria and gives the medium a green color, making it selective for tuberculosis bacteria.

questions.text: A Tzanck smear prepared from a vesicle sample revealed multinucleated giant cells. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV)

Tzanck cells or multinucleated giant cells are indicative of Herpes Simplex virus.
In genital herpes, clusters of vesicles are seen on an erythematous base along with painful and pruritic lymphadenopathy and Tzanck cells or multinucleated giant cells are seen in this condition.

questions.text: A group of 20 students in a hostel had fried rice as dinner. 6 hours later, they all experienced severe vomiting. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Bacillus cereus

The most likely causative organism in the given scenario is bacillus cereus. It causes food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption of the contaminated fried rice. Food poisoning after consumption of fried rice or Chinese street food is strongly suggestive of Bacillus cereus (Serotypes 1, 3, 5).

questions.text: A patient got pricked by a rose thorn and presents with multiple vesicles on hand and multiple eruptions along the lymphatics. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Sporothrix Schenckii

Presence of multiple vesicles on hand and multiple eruptions along lymphatics in a patient pricked by a thorn suggests infection with Sporothrix schenckii.
Sporothrix schenckii causes sporotrichosis, a chronic granulomatous disease, by traumatic inoculation into the skin. This is usually followed by spread along the draining lymphatics and lymph nodes.

questions.text: A firefighter presents with fever, cough, and lung consolidation. Microbiological testing reveals a gram-negative, oxidase-positive organism. The culture shows colonies that show a property of transillumination when light is passed. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacterium that forms greenish-yellow colonies, produces pyocyanin and fluorescein pigments, and exhibits swarming motility.

questions.text: A 42-year-old HIV patient presented with altered sensorium and impaired consciousness. India Ink examination shows positive results. Which organism is most likely to be responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cryptococcus neoformans

The given clinical scenario, along with the positive India ink stain suggests the diagnosis of Cryptococcus neoformans infection.
C. neoformans, ingested via pigeon feces, causes respiratory infections in healthy individuals and disseminates in immunocompromised patients, leading to cryptococcal meningoencephalitis with symptoms like headache and neck stiffness. It can also spread to skin, adrenals, bone, eye, and prostate.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Prevents release of acetylcholine

Botulinum toxin prevents the release of acetylcholine.
Clostridium botulinum produces neurotoxins that block acetylcholine release by cleaving SNARE proteins, causing flaccid paralysis. Ingested preformed toxins can cause food-borne botulism, with symptoms like ptosis, diplopia, dysarthria, dysphonia, and dysphagia.

questions.text:
A patient's laboratory result is positive for typhoid and Widal test findings are given below. What is the most appropriate stage of this disease?
O Ag>1:20
H Ag >1:380
A Ag>1:20
B Ag >1:20
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Reconvalescence

In this patient with suspected typhoid, the Widal test has shown only the H antigen being positive, the condition is most likely the reconvalescence phase of Typhoid.
Widal Test: This is a test for the measurement of H and O agglutinins for typhoid and paratyphoid bacilli in the patient’s sera. The antigens used in Widal’s test include:
- O antigens of S. typhi (TO)
- H antigens of S. typhi (TH)
- H antigens of S. paratyphi A (AH)
- H antigens of S. paratyphi B (BH)

Interpretation:
Demonstration of a rise in titre of antibodies by testing two or more serum samples is more meaningful than a single test.
The agglutination titer will depend on the stage of the disease: Agglutinins usually appear by the end of the first week. The titer increases steadily till the third or fourth week, after which it declines
The H agglutinins persist longer than O agglutinins.
H antibodies appear earliest after infection and persist for several months.
The O antibodies follow the appearance of H antibodies and disappear in a few weeks.
H agglutinin titer > 1/640 and O agglutinin titer >1/320 considered significant for active infection.
High H antigen titer (>1:380) with low O antigen titer (1:20) is characteristic of the recovery phase after typhoid infection hence reconvalescence phase is the correct diagnosis.

questions.text: Which organism has the following cell wall structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Gram-positive organism

The presence of teichoic acid and lipoteichoic acid with a thick peptidoglycan layer is a feature of gram-positive bacteria.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy develops bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps. The bacteria isolated from the stool specimen fermented lactose and produced colorless colonies on sorbitol MacConkey agar. The most likely etiological agent in this case is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Shiga toxin-producing E.Coli

A boy with bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps, with bacteria fermenting lactose and forming clear colonies on sorbitol MacConkey agar, likely has Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC) 0157:H7 (EHEC). Unlike other E. coli, which produce pink colonies, STEC 0157:H7 does not ferment sorbitol, resulting in colorless colonies.

questions.text: A farmer working in a paddy field presented with fever, muscle pain, nausea and vomiting. The microscopic agglutination test was positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Leptospirosis

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of leptospirosis (Weil’s disease). A microscopic agglutination test is used for the diagnosis of leptospirosis.
Leptospirosis is a zoonosis caused by spirochetes of the genus Leptospira. Patients with mild disease may present with flu-like symptoms of sudden onset, fever with chills, headache, abdominal pain, conjunctival suffusion, and myalgia. The muscle pain usually affects the calves, abdomen, and back.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presented with a fever persisting for 3 weeks. He gives a history of prosthetic valve implantation 6 months before. Investigations reveal mitral valve vegetation and is diagnosed with endocarditis. Which of the following is the most common cause of endocarditis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Staphylococcus epidermidis

This patient who underwent prosthetic valve implantation 6 months back, and currently presents with fever and mitral valve vegetations, most likely has early prosthetic valve endocarditis. The most likely causative organism is coagulase-negative staphylococci (CONS) like Staphylococcus epidermidis.
Coagulase-negative staphylococci (CONS) is the most common cause of early prosthetic valve endocarditis.

questions.text: A 9-month-old child is admitted to the ICU with a history of recurrent sinusitis and otitis media caused by Staphylococcus aureus. Lab results shows low levels of Immunoglobulins (G,A,M,E) and low quantity of plasma B cells. There is a normal reaction to environmental antigens on the skin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bruton’s agammaglobulinemia

This child’s presentation suggests X-linked or Bruton’s agammaglobulinemia.
X-linked agammaglobulinemia (Bruton agammaglobulinemia) is an immunodeficiency disorder characterized by the failure of B-cell precursors (pro-B and pre-B cells) to develop into mature B-cells. It is caused by a mutation in a cytoplasmic tyrosine kinase called Bruton tyrosine kinase (Btk) located on the long arm of the X chromosome (Xq21.22).

questions.text: For the diagnosis of Rickettsia, an antigen of Proteus is used. What is this type of antigen called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Heterophile antigen

In the diagnosis of Rickettsia infections, the heterophile antigen of Proteus is utilized in the Weil-Felix test, which is a form of heterophile agglutination reaction.
- Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction in which the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain Non-motile Proteus strains OX 19, OX 2 and OX K.
- Basis of the test is sharing of an alkali stable carbohydrate antigen by some rickettsiae and by some strains of Proteus vulgaris OX 19 & OX 2 and Proteus mirabilis OX Κ.
- OX K is agglutinated only in Scrub typhus.

questions.text: A baby is born with sensory neural deafness, patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), and salt pepper appearance on retinoscopy. Identify the infection in the mother.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Rubella

The given clinical scenario of sensorineural deafness, patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), and a salt-and-pepper appearance on retinoscopy is indicative of congenital rubella syndrome, suggesting that the mother had a rubella infection.

questions.text: A patient presents with non-pulsatile proptosis that increases when bending down. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Orbital varices

Orbital varices are venous malformations causing intermittent, non-pulsatile proptosis that worsens with bending, head lowering, or coughing and improves when upright.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy fell and injured his arm. Upon examination, a brownish-black scab is observed. What is the estimated time of injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

4-5 days

In the clinical scenario of a 10-year-old boy who fell and sustained an arm injury with a brownish scab, the estimated time of the injury is approximately 4-5 days.

choices.text: It must always be recorded by a Magistrate
An oath is not administered before recording a dying declaration.

questions.text: A boy is severely beaten by 4 to 5 people and arrives at the hospital with serious injuries. A dying declaration is recorded. Which of the following statements about dying declarations in India is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

It must always be recorded by a Magistrate

A dying declaration does not have to be recorded by a magistrate; it can be recorded by a doctor, police, or others. However, a dying deposition must always be recorded by a magistrate.

choices.text: When the family wants to reconduct the inquest

questions.text: Magistrate’s inquest is done in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Death due to police firing

Magistrate’s inquest is done in the case of death due to police firing.
Section 176 Cr.P.C. covers magistrate inquests for unnatural deaths. These inquests are conducted by district, subdivisional, or first-class magistrates, or other empowered magistrates like collectors or tehsildars.

questions.text: A person was stabbed In the thigh with a knife, resulting in a wound measuring 1 cm in length and 3 cm in depth. How would you classify this wound?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Penetrating wound

A stab wound 1 cm long and 3 cm deep is a penetrating injury, where an object breaches the skin and damages deeper tissues, potentially affecting organs, vessels, or nerves, and requiring urgent care.

questions.text: During the court proceedings, the defense lawyer asks a leading question, which the prosecutor appeals against. The judge grants the appeal. Such questions are permitted during which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cross examination

Leading questions are not allowed in all of the given options except cross-examination, i.e leading questions are allowed during cross-examination.
Section 141 of the Indian Evidence Act defines a leading question as one suggestive of the desired answer, typically requiring a yes or no. Cross-examination involves the opposing lawyer questioning the witness to test their statements, reveal facts, or discredit them.

choices.text: Attend the summons for the criminal case
Attend the summons in the civil court
Attend the court for the summons received first and inform the other court accordingly.
Inform both the courts and wait

questions.text: A doctor received a summons from the criminal court to provide evidence as an expert witness, but two days earlier, he had also received a summons from the civil court. What should the doctor do in this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Attend the summons for the criminal case

When a doctor receives a summons from the civil and criminal courts, priority should be given to attending the summons for the criminal case first.
A summons is a document compelling the attendance of a witness in a Court of law under penalty, on a particular day, time, and to give evidence.

questions.text: A body brought for autopsy was cold and had developed rigor mortis in all 4 limbs and livor mortis at the back, there is no sign of putrefaction. What is the estimated time since death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

6-12 hrs

In this case, death occurred approximately 6-12 hours ago, as rigor mortis is present but there are no signs of putrefaction. Rigor mortis, caused by muscle ATP depletion, typically appears 2-3 hours after death and lasts 12-24 hours.

questions.text:
A female died due to an unnatural cause within 7 years of marriage, and allegations have been raised. Under which section will the inquest be conducted?
BNS- Bhartiya Nyaya Sanhita
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

176 CrPC/196 BNSS

A woman who died unnaturally within 7 years of marriage suggests dowry death. Under Section 176 CrPC, a magistrate inquest is conducted by authorized magistrates like District or Sub-Divisional Magistrates when death is not natural.

questions.text: Two construction workers were working together when a hammer slipped from one worker’s hand and struck the other on the head. An X-ray revealed a fracture. What type of fracture could this be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Depressed skull fracture

The history and X-ray indicate a depressed skull fracture of the frontal bone, caused by trauma that pushes inward on the skull.

questions.text: During a forensic examination, the police presented a skull bone for analysis, and the cephalic index was determined to be 85. Which race does the skull likely belong to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Mongoloids

A skull bone with a cephalic index of 85 belongs to the Mongoloid race.
Cephalic Index is used to determine the race of the individual.
Cranial index = Maximum skull breadth x 100/ Maximum skull length.
There are three main racial groups: Caucasian, Mongoloid and Negroid. All the skulls cannot be accurately differentiated into the 3 broad categories because of the racial mixing.
